intro: Acalypha obovata var. cuneata, commonly known as the narrow-leaf spurge-plant, is a species of flowering plant in the family Euphorbiaceae. It is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, particularly India and Southeast Asia. The plant features alternate, ovate to lanceolate leaves with a smooth or slightly hairy surface. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are clustered in cyathia, typical of the Euphorbiaceae family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forest understories or along stream banks.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha obovata var. cuneata is primarily native to Southeast Asia, including countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines. It is commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in lowland areas with moist, well-drained soils. This variant thrives in humid environments and is often associated with forest understories or secondary growth habitats. It is also known to occur in parts of Australia, particularly in the northern regions. The plant is well adapted to warm climates and is often used in ornamental horticulture due to its attractive foliage.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha obovata var. cuneata was mainly introduced to New Zealand as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. It was first recorded in the 19th century and has since become established in several regions of the country. The plant is commonly found in urban and rural areas, often growing along roadsides and in disturbed soils. Its introduction has raised concerns due to its potential to spread and compete with native vegetation. Despite its ornamental value, it is now considered a potential weed in some parts of New Zealand.
